number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Okay I just want to say something before I get into the mechanics and present of the games standing. A couple years ago i purchased this game on the playstation 3 where it's player base was far higher than the number that you see today. The game had amazing mechanics and delivered beyond my expectations. This game had the feeling of Overwatch (A game coming mid 2016), the colour of dirty bomb and the fun of team fortress. The game died QUICKLY as many newer FPS games came to brush this masterpiece off. Now thats out of the way let me discuss what you can still do now. The singleplayer is still a fast paced interesting action filled shooter with multiple gamemodes, similar to games you see today. If you were able to to experience this game with your friends and compete with or against them, you will have hours upon days of fun. Now if thinking of purchasing this game, I would like you to think first, am I going to be open to the games singleplayer and/or should I recommend this game to my friends and play with them to maximise my playtime. The games price should not be as high as it currently is but the game is real fun and I enjoyed it. 9/10 during its time,  6.5/10 in todays standing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 2, 2012
												BRINK /would/ be an awesome team-oriented shooter if there was actually more than 5 people online playing it -- on the same server.  This game seriously could have been really good, but there is just a few things wrong with it that don't work that well.  The bots are just horrible, mainly due to their inability to prioritize for objectives.  Also, undisguising as a spy behind a bot will give you away, but if you sneak up behind them undiguised them they will not notice.  The bots have to be the most gamebreaking of all.  The SMART movement is weird to get used to at first, but it becomes a lot easier if you just let it do the work for you, instead of trying to mash jump, crouch, and sprint like you would in other games.  The core game mechanics are actually really good, the secondary objectives offer a twist to traditional team-based objective gameplay, and it's actually very playable overall. This game could have been great, but alas, it just doesn't have the community support.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 2, 2011
												The game is not♥♥♥♥♥♥ but it is the definition of mediocre. For everything the game does well (parkouring) it loses in its absolutely terrible map design, weapon "upgrade" (read replacement) systems, as well as its mission. Weapons are either ridiculously strong, or so weak as to be puny.The mission objectives system is nicely implemented but does not taking into consideration such things as "that big♥♥♥♥♥♥♥wall in the way". The missions themselves are likewise poorly constructed and suffer far too much from "narrow hallway, open exposed mission area, and enemys spawn on top of your mission objective"It's never clear enough precisely what areas are parkourable and which areas are walls that you just can't touch.To give it, its positives the combat can be engaging at times - the character creator is interesting but as a point of annoyance - you can only create male characters. The entire game world is composed entirely of males.tl;dr - buy something else.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 27, 2011
												Brink brings several new and unique concepts and mechanics to the world of first person shooters in very comprehensible ways, and, unlike most modern shooters nowadays, players have enough health to survive the first couple of shots in a gunfight and have a chance to retaliate or attempt to escape to cover; this isn't your arcade-y style run-and-gun Call of Duty or Battlefield, but a game that requires more precise aiming and control over yourself and your weapon. Unfortunately, Brink suffered from one severely debilitating setback: it was over-hyped so much that its failure was guaranteed from the outset. The beautiful environments influenced but not overtaken by science fiction elements are a sight to behold, and the music fits very appropriately, but it's all brought down by the developers' hubris. Know that the game is very entertaining, but, at the time of this writing, there isn't enough of an active online community to be worth the investment.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 4, 2011
												This game is defiantly geared more towards hardcore gamers that enjoy dynamic gameplay and the devs took the pretty ambitious idea of adding La Parkor mechanics and incorporate them into a FPS while still keeping it accessible to gamers of all types.  I think they made it work well, but it feels as if you are playing the piano on your keyboard... and I'm talking Mozart Piano Concerto No. 20, not chopsticks.  You'll need a higher end keyboard to make sure it can handle many keys simultaneous pressed at once.It has the feel of Quake II's controlled action mixed with Mirror's Edge La Parkor acrobatic gameplay and  BF:BC2's class based game play and in-depth weapon customization system.  The NeoTokyo source engine mod is the only game I can really think of that this most similarly resembles, and I enjoyed that mod a lot. If you did to then there is a good chance you'll enjoy this as much as I have.At $25 it's a fair deal, anything more isn't worth it due to the lack of maps available.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2011
												A great FPS with an original backstory. Added dynamic movement brings a new style of combat to the field along with hightened recoil and gun firing stability factor make it a tougher game to be a competent killer at in multiplayer.The game had a huge hype rating, and although it didn't pull through entirely, the concept was what caught us. Being able to leap over anything, sprint-slide, and wall jump added new heights to maps that would normally be linear.Added classes and ability system, gun customization, and character customization, bring total player customization and a RPG style to the game. This is a great game to play and I pick it up every once in a while.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 27, 2011
												A masterpiece unguilty of its own failureBRINK was and still is one of my favourite MP-FPS-games I ever played.The problem is there are few actually playing it, also from people that played it I only heard things like "bad game" and such.I for myself could've been one of them. If I wouldn't have read the conclusion of a writer of a (now no more excisting) magazine.Quote: "You MUST NOT play this as a game where you go like "BOOM HEADSHOT". This is a game you can not enjoy this way. But you WILL enjoy it - promise - if you play it with teamplay and the common goal in mind."I'm incredible greatful to that guy who wrote that and allowed me to enjoy this game.The problem of this game is not its complexity, it has. The problem is not the beefy heavies, dominating CQ. The problem this game has is the FPS-community. The problem is not everybody who played this game read that article, or even wants to play towards a common goal. That is the problem of the game. If you truly want to play together with others, this game is one you should try. But you should not touch it as a shooter, but as a "Common Goal Action Game".

												Brink is a fantastic take on the FPS genre. Following similar style to TF2, Brink offers everything CoD doesn't, teamwork, full gun and character customization, class based combat and co-op. What's to hate? Majority of the critics are stupid fools playing on Xbox who have a mind set of, CoD CoD CoD CoD, Call of Duty isn't everything! number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												So this one time I was playing Dystopia, and then everyone stopped playing Dystopia because of all the bugs. Luckily, the guys at Bethesda and Splash Damage realized that the best way to get us all back into Dystopia was to create a game that made Dystopia's bugs look much more pleasant by comparison. And so, Brink was created. Thanks to Brink, I've played more Dystopia in the last month than I have been playing in the last year! It's just like that episode of Star Trek The Next Generation where Data has to outsmart his holographic nemesis Professor Moriarty by tricking him into thinking he was somewhere else. Brink tricks you into thinking you like it, but unlike Moriarty most of us are smart enough to realize that we should really just be playing Dystopia, for ♥♥♥♥'s sake. Do yourself a favour and get Dystopia. It's like Brink except much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, much, better.

												Brink makes you feel when you are proceeding through the objectives or defending your area. The downside is when teams are uneven and all you do is get spawn camped and boned. While the maps are small (About 14 maps between challenge and normal), they contain lots of compact area's and pathways. However most of the levels are kind of ugly looking with no open areas.I was mostly interested in the game because of its ability to travel around, wall jump, and quickly move into combat areas. In the actual online multiplayer game I found that no one does it because you'll get shot and killed quite quickly.My overall review is that the game is good, but flawed because of the lack of content, classes, and the shoddy environments.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Let's be truly honest here.Sometimes, playing with real people tends to get on your nerves. Whether it be people who don't know how VOIP works or just idiots trying to ruin a game for everyone, sometimes you just don't want your mind to be muddled and just want to hunker down after a hard day's work.In the following paragraphs, I'm going to tell you how BRINK can give you that and so much more.BRINK has had a rather unsteady history. I was one of the few people who bought it at launch and actually experienced it's rather disastrous start.It was a mess. Massive lag hampered the game as well as netcode issues plaguing even dedicated servers. It also didn't help that ATI card didn't even run the game properly, and it even had problems on the Nvidia side of things!So BRINK's launch-that-was-not ruined its reputation with the community, and sadly, a lot of people abandoned it as a failure.I, however, did not. Determined to get the bang for my buck, I and many other souls soldiered on with the game. And that's where it started to show its greatest strengths both as a competitive and casual shooter. Let me talk about a few of these.For those like me, who are not interested in playing with real players due to the stress or those who just simply don't have good internet connection, BRINK still allows you to play the game the way it's meant to be played through a single player (or co-op) bot mode.Now I do admit, the bots were way underdeveloped when the game first released, but Splash Damage, even with the mostly negative reviews, didn't abandon the game and continued to patch it, which I believe the company should be lauded for.At the games current build, the bots are smart, strategic, and will keep you on your toes. Even on normal difficulty you see the bots employing new strategies to outsmart you. They will play the objective and they will play it well, and you can rely on the enemy team to keep up the tense firefights.In my almost 100 hours of play, I've seen bots use every ability available to the average player, even the ones you unlock at the highest level! These bots have come a long way from simple peashooters, and now are a decisive enemy that can be the fuel for hours of entertainment.Sadly, the servers have been long dead for this game for a while, so bots are the only option if you want to play this game. I find this to be a shame, since BRINK was an excellent competitive shooter to. I'll get to that in a momentNow you might be asking "Why play a game with bots? Where's the drive to keep me playing?" Let me show you.BRINK used a system called "Mingleplayer". What that basically means is that you can play the game however you want, without the game punishing you. Wanna just play with bots solo? You can and can still gain experience and levels! Wanna play the games as an ultra competitive shooter? You can do that to (at least, you could if the game still had servers. Though you could always copy the competitive format of the game into a custom bot game, a feature in itself that has given me hours of entertainment). BRINK rewards you, however you want to play the game, and that for me is it's biggest strength.Aside from that, BRINK made for an excellent competitive game as well. Way back when my online experience was almost entirely 5v5 scrims. That's the beauty of BRINK, it can be played both as a casual shooter where you join a server and blast away and as a highly competitive team shooter, voice comms and all. Each class (Medic, Engineer, Soldier, and Operative) had their distinct roles in the battlefield. Every class had its own skill tree and abilities, allowing you to customize to your playstyle. At the highest levels of play, all sorts of gadgets could be used from healing fields to UAVs. This gave BRINK endless replayability both at the lowest levels of play and the highest levels of play.So you might be asking, why buy a dead game? Well, you'll just have to trust me on this one. Splash Damage gave this game the support it deserved and it has grown beautifully into a hidden gem. I can guarantee you the bots will give you a run for your money and you will have a great time with this game. The game is a beautiful tragedy, as it didn't get to reach its full potential in its lifetime, but can still offer you countless hours of offline bot play. I heartedly recommend this game to anyone who has an itchy trigger finger, and wants something new in their fps library!So after a hard day's work, BRINK's got you covered. No screaming children. No Trolls. No idiots.Just you and the game.BONUS: The only fundamental DLC is Agent of Change, as it adds two new missions and several abilities and attachments, as well as raises the level cap. The others are purely cosmetic.Thanks for reading!

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												This was supposed to be a good game. An objective based team multiplayer FPS from the developers of Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory and Enemy Territory: Quake Wars? It sounds like it should be the next best thing in online FPS gaming, but sadly, this turned out to not be the case. The art direction and the free running mechanic is pretty much all there is that's good about this game. Poor gun mechanics, poor controls, poor optimization, a community that was nearly dead as soon as the game launched, poor server browser, and practically no post release support all helped in putting Brink into an early grave. Gamers buried this one alive while it still had life in it, because there was just no future hope for this title. Seeing how Splash Damage is now developing a new free to play FPS called Dirty Bomb, the chances of this going free to play are basically zero, so this game is as good as dead now.Here's hoping that Splash Damage has learned from their mistakes with Brink...

												A masterpiece unguilty of its own failureBRINK was and still is one of my favourite MP-FPS-games I ever played.The problem is there are few actually playing it, also from people that played it I only heard things like "bad game" and such.I for myself could've been one of them. If you truly want to play together with others, this game is one you should try. But you should not touch it as a shooter, but as a "Common Goal Action Game".

content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												Where BRINK does some things right, it does many things wrong. When it becomes fun, it has the possibility of becoming equally frustrating. When things start to get exciting, they suddenly become tedious.BRINK had a lot of ambition. A parkour-driven first person shooter with on-the-fly objectives and a campaign that could be played online in both factions at the same time sounded ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic and should have been a recipe for overnight success. Sadly those joyous mechanics were not executed to their fullest potential and the online play was plagued with problems on day one. Now you are lucky to find anyone to play with and playing with the AI can be more frustrating than playing with some hacker ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ online.BRINK is not a bad game, nor is it a good game. It is sadly middle of the road and that hurts. I recommend it only if it is cheap so you can see the makings of what could have been.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												Brink made it's debut as a fast-paced parkour shooter, and to this end it has been successful. Wall-jumping, vaulting, and sliding into enemies to knock them off their feet are all movement-based features integrated into the game. Players can also heavily customize their characters features, such as weight, tattoos, scars, clothing, ect. To a slightly lesser degree, they can also customize their weapons, adding muzzle brakes and scopes. The gameplay is fast, hectic, and the more you play, the more abilities you can bring to bear on the enemy. The environments are varied, and some of them can be quite beautiful, but aren't more explorable, or impressed upon the player, which is a shame, because some maps really have a lot of potential. To be honest, the story mode is quick, generates more questions than answers, and doesn't have all that great of a story in and of itself. You can take the sides of either the Resistance or the Ark Security forces, fighting each other for the fate of Ark. Nonetheless, story notwithstanding, the action is fast, gunplay better, and for sure this game is worth a try at least. Overall Score: 9.5/10

Go buy TF2 instead.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Let's be truly honest here.Sometimes, playing with real people tends to get on your nerves. Whether it be people who don't know how VOIP works or just idiots trying to ruin a game for everyone, sometimes you just don't want your mind to be muddled and just want to hunker down after a hard day's work.In the following paragraphs, I'm going to tell you how BRINK can give you that and so much more.BRINK has had a rather unsteady history. I was one of the few people who bought it at launch and actually experienced it's rather disastrous start.It was a mess. Massive lag hampered the game as well as netcode issues plaguing even dedicated servers. It also didn't help that ATI card didn't even run the game properly, and it even had problems on the Nvidia side of things!So BRINK's launch-that-was-not ruined its reputation with the community, and sadly, a lot of people abandoned it as a failure.I, however, did not. Determined to get the bang for my buck, I and many other souls soldiered on with the game. And that's where it started to show its greatest strengths both as a competitive and casual shooter. Let me talk about a few of these.For those like me, who are not interested in playing with real players due to the stress or those who just simply don't have good internet connection, BRINK still allows you to play the game the way it's meant to be played through a single player (or co-op) bot mode.Now I do admit, the bots were way underdeveloped when the game first released, but Splash Damage, even with the mostly negative reviews, didn't abandon the game and continued to patch it, which I believe the company should be lauded for.At the games current build, the bots are smart, strategic, and will keep you on your toes. Even on normal difficulty you see the bots employing new strategies to outsmart you. They will play the objective and they will play it well, and you can rely on the enemy team to keep up the tense firefights.In my almost 100 hours of play, I've seen bots use every ability available to the average player, even the ones you unlock at the highest level! These bots have come a long way from simple peashooters, and now are a decisive enemy that can be the fuel for hours of entertainment.Sadly, the servers have been long dead for this game for a while, so bots are the only option if you want to play this game. I find this to be a shame, since BRINK was an excellent competitive shooter to. I'll get to that in a momentNow you might be asking "Why play a game with bots? Where's the drive to keep me playing?" Let me show you.BRINK used a system called "Mingleplayer". What that basically means is that you can play the game however you want, without the game punishing you. Wanna just play with bots solo? You can and can still gain experience and levels! Wanna play the games as an ultra competitive shooter? You can do that to (at least, you could if the game still had servers. Though you could always copy the competitive format of the game into a custom bot game, a feature in itself that has given me hours of entertainment). BRINK rewards you, however you want to play the game, and that for me is it's biggest strength.Aside from that, BRINK made for an excellent competitive game as well. Way back when my online experience was almost entirely 5v5 scrims. That's the beauty of BRINK, it can be played both as a casual shooter where you join a server and blast away and as a highly competitive team shooter, voice comms and all. Each class (Medic, Engineer, Soldier, and Operative) had their distinct roles in the battlefield. Every class had its own skill tree and abilities, allowing you to customize to your playstyle. At the highest levels of play, all sorts of gadgets could be used from healing fields to UAVs. This gave BRINK endless replayability both at the lowest levels of play and the highest levels of play.So you might be asking, why buy a dead game? Well, you'll just have to trust me on this one. Splash Damage gave this game the support it deserved and it has grown beautifully into a hidden gem. I can guarantee you the bots will give you a run for your money and you will have a great time with this game. The game is a beautiful tragedy, as it didn't get to reach its full potential in its lifetime, but can still offer you countless hours of offline bot play. I heartedly recommend this game to anyone who has an itchy trigger finger, and wants something new in their fps library!So after a hard day's work, BRINK's got you covered. No screaming children. No Trolls. No idiots.Just you and the game.BONUS: The only fundamental DLC is Agent of Change, as it adds two new missions and several abilities and attachments, as well as raises the level cap. The others are purely cosmetic.Thanks for reading!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 12, 2011
												Brink is something of a confusing topic in the office. We're pretty split down the middle in terms of supporters or detractors, and there seems to be a common thread: Team Fortress 2 players, like the hardcore ones, will not like this game. Everyone else might enjoy it for what it is -- a squad based shooter that REQUIRES teamwork to succeed. If you play online, most people you run into will play really well, but there are a few players that ruin the experience. I'm going to go with a toss up for this one. If you and the rest of your baseball team sized group of friends want to get pumped up before a game or something, this might be for you. If you have a lack of friends who like to play fps games, or are already into TF2, pass.

												This game is a prime example of great ideas with very poor execution. The graphics, sound, and general game-play mechanics are fun overall, but the game structure, objectives, and storyline are extremely shallow. Maps are cool at first but feel repetitive after a short while playing. The biggest disappointment is probably the coop campaign, which feels like multiplayer with bots, both in its lack of direction or purpose and in its aimlessly inspired level designs. The $50 price tag is far from justified. I would estimate this game worth a paltry $10.00; good enough for the occasional distraction, but don't get your expectations up.  Score: 5 out of 10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												This was supposed to be a good game. An objective based team multiplayer FPS from the developers of Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory and Enemy Territory: Quake Wars? It sounds like it should be the next best thing in online FPS gaming, but sadly, this turned out to not be the case. The art direction and the free running mechanic is pretty much all there is that's good about this game. Poor gun mechanics, poor controls, poor optimization, a community that was nearly dead as soon as the game launched, poor server browser, and practically no post release support all helped in putting Brink into an early grave. Gamers buried this one alive while it still had life in it, because there was just no future hope for this title. Seeing how Splash Damage is now developing a new free to play FPS called Dirty Bomb, the chances of this going free to play are basically zero, so this game is as good as dead now.Here's hoping that Splash Damage has learned from their mistakes with Brink...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Let's be truly honest here.Sometimes, playing with real people tends to get on your nerves. Whether it be people who don't know how VOIP works or just idiots trying to ruin a game for everyone, sometimes you just don't want your mind to be muddled and just want to hunker down after a hard day's work.In the following paragraphs, I'm going to tell you how BRINK can give you that and so much more.BRINK has had a rather unsteady history. I was one of the few people who bought it at launch and actually experienced it's rather disastrous start.It was a mess. Massive lag hampered the game as well as netcode issues plaguing even dedicated servers. It also didn't help that ATI card didn't even run the game properly, and it even had problems on the Nvidia side of things!So BRINK's launch-that-was-not ruined its reputation with the community, and sadly, a lot of people abandoned it as a failure.I, however, did not. Determined to get the bang for my buck, I and many other souls soldiered on with the game. And that's where it started to show its greatest strengths both as a competitive and casual shooter. Let me talk about a few of these.For those like me, who are not interested in playing with real players due to the stress or those who just simply don't have good internet connection, BRINK still allows you to play the game the way it's meant to be played through a single player (or co-op) bot mode.Now I do admit, the bots were way underdeveloped when the game first released, but Splash Damage, even with the mostly negative reviews, didn't abandon the game and continued to patch it, which I believe the company should be lauded for.At the games current build, the bots are smart, strategic, and will keep you on your toes. Even on normal difficulty you see the bots employing new strategies to outsmart you. They will play the objective and they will play it well, and you can rely on the enemy team to keep up the tense firefights.In my almost 100 hours of play, I've seen bots use every ability available to the average player, even the ones you unlock at the highest level! These bots have come a long way from simple peashooters, and now are a decisive enemy that can be the fuel for hours of entertainment.Sadly, the servers have been long dead for this game for a while, so bots are the only option if you want to play this game. I find this to be a shame, since BRINK was an excellent competitive shooter to. I'll get to that in a momentNow you might be asking "Why play a game with bots? Where's the drive to keep me playing?" Let me show you.BRINK used a system called "Mingleplayer". What that basically means is that you can play the game however you want, without the game punishing you. Wanna just play with bots solo? You can and can still gain experience and levels! Wanna play the games as an ultra competitive shooter? You can do that to (at least, you could if the game still had servers. Though you could always copy the competitive format of the game into a custom bot game, a feature in itself that has given me hours of entertainment). BRINK rewards you, however you want to play the game, and that for me is it's biggest strength.Aside from that, BRINK made for an excellent competitive game as well. Way back when my online experience was almost entirely 5v5 scrims. That's the beauty of BRINK, it can be played both as a casual shooter where you join a server and blast away and as a highly competitive team shooter, voice comms and all. Each class (Medic, Engineer, Soldier, and Operative) had their distinct roles in the battlefield. Every class had its own skill tree and abilities, allowing you to customize to your playstyle. At the highest levels of play, all sorts of gadgets could be used from healing fields to UAVs. This gave BRINK endless replayability both at the lowest levels of play and the highest levels of play.So you might be asking, why buy a dead game? Well, you'll just have to trust me on this one. Splash Damage gave this game the support it deserved and it has grown beautifully into a hidden gem. I can guarantee you the bots will give you a run for your money and you will have a great time with this game. The game is a beautiful tragedy, as it didn't get to reach its full potential in its lifetime, but can still offer you countless hours of offline bot play. I heartedly recommend this game to anyone who has an itchy trigger finger, and wants something new in their fps library!So after a hard day's work, BRINK's got you covered. No screaming children. No Trolls. No idiots.Just you and the game.BONUS: The only fundamental DLC is Agent of Change, as it adds two new missions and several abilities and attachments, as well as raises the level cap. The others are purely cosmetic.Thanks for reading!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2011
												"It's about saying, are you going to come in and play or not? Because if you're not, we're not going to accommodate you, to let you be part of and involved in this intimacy." That's Splash Damage's Richard Ham speaking to my indie gaming blog this week on BRINK, his company's latest.And while the dimpled electronic polygons of BRINK do make for close encounters, Splash Damage's overtly sexual couplets provide a slinky analog to the visuals at play. In "Container City", an aesthetic marvel in its own right, they use frustrating gameplay to proffer a few grunts, howls, and moans. But again, what makes this all work so well is the remarkable amount of restraint and freerunning know-how these developers employ. This company has come a long way in that regard-- it's not easy to integrate the sounds of "gun" into "game" without coming off like the kind of guy with a favorite tree from which to creep.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 12, 2011
												Don't buy this. Not now, not ever. Even though the main selling point is movement, maps don't reflect that, and you can jump higher in Battlefield Bad Company 2.The weapon balance is pathetic: Heavy weapons are useless, medium weapons are unnecessary and the only light weapon worth a damn is the Bulpdein.The maps are tiny and claustrophobic, even when the game tries to give you a big environment, there's no helping that feeling when you can only ever run along a few corridors in there. Despite the movement system, there's almost no vertical combat, at any given time, the most number of floors you'll see is two, and even then there's virtually no chance that being on either gives you much advantage.The UI looks like it was made by someone who'd only heard of an FPS once. Everything is opposite of where you'd expect and nothing looks explicitly like it should. The radar, in particular needs a border, and more flamboyant blips.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 21, 2012
												EDIT:  I'm leaving the full review here, just so you can see, but I have to change to negative.  Brink itself isn't a terrible game (read below if you want to read why I think that), BUT it has no real community to play with and there are newer, better FPS games in all styles.  I suggest checking out Pay Day 2 and Counter Strike: Global Offensive (if you're not a big fan of the standard competeive CS mode, check out Deathmatch and Arms Race, so much fun).Original Review:  A lot has been said about Brink, and a lot of it has been negative.  I must point out that a lot of the bad press the game recieved on launch was due to technical issues on consoles, not on PC.  There were a few minor issues on PC, but all has been fixed with updates to the game.Upon first playing Brink I thought it was brilliant.  The objective system, which gaves you actual goals to accomplish instead of just capturing points, flags, or getting kills, was unique and made the first few hours of gameplay feel new and different, despite otherwise being a standard team-based FPS.  The parkour system is also unique and allows you to traverse levels in interesting ways that other FPS's never will.These combined, plus a neat art aesthetic and customizable characters, made me really enjoy Brink at first.That said, the game didn't really seem to last long for me.  Perhaps it was the fact that the multiplayer is essentially dead (due to the bad rep the game had on release), or maybe the objective system, though unique at first, in practice only seems adds a simple layer on top of "capture this point" mechanics after a couple matches.Maybe the gunplay just doesn't hold up as well to other giants of the FPS genre (specifically Battlefield, as that's what I've had the msot experience with).In short, if you don't mind bot games (or can convince friends to join you), this game is good for perhaps a few hours of FPS fun, but you'll probably get tired of it after 5 or so hours.  I'd say if it's on sale for five bucks, why not give it a shot?  But otherwise, you might as well avoid.Leaving this as a recommendation for the positives, and I would say give it a shot if you can get it cheap and especially if you have friends to play with, so it doesn't exactly deserve a no.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2011
												While it is easy to find a review or detailed information on a game such as this one, it is no doubt the best option to try out the game to get the 'feeling' of how it is. Brink being an FPS game, is slightly different than other FPS games in terms of the following facts:1) Strongly focused on Team Work. If you like to work in a group and don't want to gun blaze into a fight and try to prove you are better than others (which is pointless), then this is the game for you.2) Parkour. David Belle's parkour makes its (probably) second return in gaming world. Being able to move around the environment using parkour is great but you should be aware of the fact that only Light Body and Medium Body types get to do them, as oppose to the Heavy Body types. The trade off lies in which weapon you can carry based on the body type you choose. 3) Get it if you are tired of playing mediocre game like Call of Duty. :D

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 17, 2011
												I'll be up front: BRINK's promises of extensive customization and a seamless singleplayer/multiplayer experience are just so much hype, thankfully only in very specific ways. The customization of the characters isn't as detailed and indepth as several on-hand video demos pre-release made it seem to be, and the Artifical Intelligence? They're useless on non-defense objectives for the most part, since offensive teams swarm too tightly and too furiously for your disorganized AI companions to be much help.However, BRINK's encouragement of objective focus rather than kill focused teamwork and gameplay REALLY help to make the ONLINE experience a joy: Players are more likely to assist and work together to achieve a goal than in most other team and class focused games I've played. SMARTS works great, and will be 'stolen' for use in other games, I suspect.My advice? Buy only if interested in the theme and style of the game.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2011
												Endlich kommt es einmal nicht nur auf die K/D an. In diesem schnellen und Objecitve basierten Mulitplayer-Shooter ist Teamplay das A und O. Selbst der versierteste Schütze kommt nicht weit wenn er sich nicht nach seinen Mitspielern umsieht. Die Karten sind abwechsungsreich und spannend designt. Auch nach vielen Stunden entdeckt man noch neue Wege. Top: Was man offline freischaltet darf man auch online verwenden! Trotzdem kann man keinen Über-Char erstellen. Durch das (großzügige) Levelcap ist man angehalten herauszufinden welche Fähigkeiten zum eigenen Spieltyp passen und diese dan clever auswählen. Gelungen auch die Bots. Sie erfüllen Ziele. Sie verteidigen. Sie flankieren. Sie nehmen Komandoposten. Sie greifen in Wellen an. Sie legen gegen Ende der Partie noch zu. Sie sliden um Dich zu Fall zu bringen... Vor allem aber: Sind sie unterstützen Dich mit "Buffs" und das zum Teil deutlich effektiver als mancher Spawn-Chiller, den ich online im Team hatte :-)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Putting aside the hatred for this game regarding initial advertising, I still found it very appealing. To this day, I enjoy a couple of hours of Brink every now and then. I only wish the multiplayer scene wasn't completely dead. This would attract more gamers, I'd imagine. The gameplay is standard FPS fare with a little parkour thrown into the mix. The basic plot is, well, very basic, but it's the audio logs you unlock through gameplay that is to me an allegory for human nature. Both the Security forces attempting to protect the Ark and the Resistance forces attempting to flee the Ark make so many errors and foolish moves. Through pride, anger and personal resentment, the two opposing factions tear each other apart when it was so easily avoided if either side had stymied their rage long enough to come to a reasonable solution. You are told how the Ark is falling apart because the resources that keep it functional are being used to manufacture ammunition to fight the Security forces, and how Ark Security is unwilling to venture outside of the Ark to find signs of civilisation due to an incident many years earlier which resulted in the deaths of an expeditionary team previously dispatched. All in all, the story is great. Neither side is good or bad. both are wrong and right in their own way and both really screw things up in their own way. As I said, an allegory for human nature. If you're interested in the single player campaign, I recommend it, but the multiplayer scene is long dead.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												This game was weirdly received so I'll try to provide some clarity. It's a good time if you wanna play a different shooter and mod a character and guns to fit the role you've chosen. The Lamented Features: The "Campaign" is multiplayer missions with bots. Challenges aren't a static difficulty as they will adopt a higher difficulty, causing some to be nigh impossible. Do them first on easy to ensure they're completed.Harder Bots have insane accuracy, requiring around the corner tactics, especially when grouped on an objective. Some objectives require time, and if interupted will be reset. The Sweetness:The Free Running is fun and useful. Character and Weapon Customization is really fun and strategic. I miss it. The Music is great. The Character Art Style is interesting, and well enough received it's in future titles. The Levels are cool looking, ranging from start futurism to busy slums. Fun Mission Types

												This game is a prime example of great ideas with very poor execution. The graphics, sound, and general game-play mechanics are fun overall, but the game structure, objectives, and storyline are extremely shallow. Maps are cool at first but feel repetitive after a short while playing. The biggest disappointment is probably the coop campaign, which feels like multiplayer with bots, both in its lack of direction or purpose and in its aimlessly inspired level designs. The $50 price tag is far from justified. I would estimate this game worth a paltry $10.00; good enough for the occasional distraction, but don't get your expectations up.  Score: 5 out of 10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 20, 2012
												Brink is an objective based multiplayer shooter that took me some getting used to. Most of my early hours, I was pretty much just killing bad guys while being completely lost on what the objectives were. Now that I have a few more hours under my belt and have gotten used to the gameplay, I must confess it's pretty fun. It's highly action packed, but the objectives are just not obvious to new players.The game puts significant emphasis on customization in both character looks and loadouts--for example being able to select two primary weapons is nice. The graphics are solid, the gameplay is smooth, and the character leveling is implemented well. It also throws in a decent storyline which is uncommon in these type of multiplayer games. But don't buy Brink because of its single player or coop claims. It disappoints unless you consider playing multiplayer with bots fun.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												== SHORT ==I like it, I am happy that I bought it and I feel like I've been delivered the hapiness that I payed for.If you like team and class based FPS and love to customize your character, go ahead, this game is for you.== LONG ==When I came across teaser of this game for first time, I was quite impressed. It promised, super nice movement possibilities and seamless multiplayer/singleplayer experience. Well... They did what they promised in some way. :DSingle/Multiplayer is just simply multiplayer with somewhat storyline, which you can play through with bots, too :) Storyline is a bit more than you would expect from MP game (which is good!), but not really a single player story.Movement capabilities are really there. It's like almost only thing that you can't do is climb tall vertical walls. The rest is possible. Of course, my playing style is more "close and personal", which caused me to choose Heavy body type which is... more...inert than Light body type... So, not that much climbing for me :DCharacter customization, level ups, upgrades, weapons, weapon customization, class based gameplay is very well tuned, too :) Even now from time to time I am enjoying it with my Heavy Enforcer and a Gatling Gun (or something it is called... Essentially, 3 barrel minigun :D )

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												It's Call of Duty, but better. I never really liked Call of Duty, with it's "factory line" to a nother chest-high pile of sandbags, or other useless junk, but this game bought more realism to what I thought should be CoD. It actually kind of combines both Battlefield and CoD, even a little bit of it's own special sauce. You can wall jump, different types of characters, slide across those boring chest high walls, and fart on them along the way. One problem though: graphics. There's something wrong with their faces, but it's not something a man with and editing program can fix to make their faces look less oval-y. With custom weapons, (slightly) underpowered grenades, and an army of a 8/10 grade AI by your side, you'll be the best cop/criminal to ever walk the Ark. Just don't think the bots are dumb, because they aren't, even on the easiest difficulty. I found myself throwing grenades and (unproffessionally) firing my gun everywhere because I was scared by how skilled they were. Then I figured out all you have to do is melee them, THEN fire your gun in their face. Mush all that boring review stuff together, and you get a 9/10. Good job, Splash damage and Bethesda. You amazed me once, let's see you do it again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 13, 2012
												The thing about game reviews is, that they can seriously dampen the interest for great games that just happen to recieve mediocre reviews. BRINK is such a game. It's an FPS with a storyline (cutscenes and all) but it's actually meant to be played in co-op with several players. On both sides. And it works so damn well, with graphics that remind you of "Waterworld" and parkour elements that are even better than Mirror's Edge. And an emphasis team tactics, that actually matters. You like FPS team multiplayer games with a good storyline to back it up? Then I suggest you try out BRINK, preferably with a friend or two.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												Don't get it. It was probably good at some point, but is now unplayable.My first 20 minutes of gametime I spent trying to get it to work in the first place. The game apparently can't handle my GPU properly so it always crashed on mission startup when I put the resolution to 1920x1080. Had to put it to 1600x900... there's also no option (at least not ingame) to play in windowed mode, so that kinda sucks.Then I tried to play the campaign but either I am incredibly stupid or that only works online, too??? I was in a room filled with bots but couldn't move because my ping was over 500. The only thing that worked offline was the training...Recently I tried to launch it in Offline Mode... bad idea! It just didn't launch at all. So I went back to Steams default Online Mode and... somehow BRINK still won't start. I don't know why, but not allowing it internet access somehow broke it completely. I could probably try to verify the games contents to fix it, but what for, honestly?In short: Most of the time it will crash or not even launch at all, you can't play online because no body else plays it anymore in the first place and the servers are messed up, if you planned on buying it merely for the campaign: that only works via the potato servers as well, even when besides you there's only bots in the room. You can't play. You literally can't play. (Unless you wanna play with crazy bad connection, feeling like a toddler having trouble taking every single step. Which, to be honest, sounds like a somewhat fun description, but trust me, in a partially parcour based game toddlers just don't have it easy!)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 12, 2011
												While it is easy to find a review or detailed information on a game such as this one, it is no doubt the best option to try out the game to get the 'feeling' of how it is. Brink being an FPS game, is slightly different than other FPS games in terms of the following facts:1) Strongly focused on Team Work. If you like to work in a group and don't want to gun blaze into a fight and try to prove you are better than others (which is pointless), then this is the game for you.2) Parkour. David Belle's parkour makes its (probably) second return in gaming world. Being able to move around the environment using parkour is great but you should be aware of the fact that only Light Body and Medium Body types get to do them, as oppose to the Heavy Body types. The trade off lies in which weapon you can carry based on the body type you choose. 3) Get it if you are tired of playing mediocre game like Call of Duty. :D

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 17, 2011
												I'll be up front: BRINK's promises of extensive customization and a seamless singleplayer/multiplayer experience are just so much hype, thankfully only in very specific ways. The customization of the characters isn't as detailed and indepth as several on-hand video demos pre-release made it seem to be, and the Artifical Intelligence? They're useless on non-defense objectives for the most part, since offensive teams swarm too tightly and too furiously for your disorganized AI companions to be much help.However, BRINK's encouragement of objective focus rather than kill focused teamwork and gameplay REALLY help to make the ONLINE experience a joy: Players are more likely to assist and work together to achieve a goal than in most other team and class focused games I've played. SMARTS works great, and will be 'stolen' for use in other games, I suspect.My advice? Buy only if interested in the theme and style of the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 21, 2015
												Brink made it's debut as a fast-paced parkour shooter, and to this end it has been successful. Wall-jumping, vaulting, and sliding into enemies to knock them off their feet are all movement-based features integrated into the game. Players can also heavily customize their characters features, such as weight, tattoos, scars, clothing, ect. To a slightly lesser degree, they can also customize their weapons, adding muzzle brakes and scopes. The gameplay is fast, hectic, and the more you play, the more abilities you can bring to bear on the enemy. The environments are varied, and some of them can be quite beautiful, but aren't more explorable, or impressed upon the player, which is a shame, because some maps really have a lot of potential. To be honest, the story mode is quick, generates more questions than answers, and doesn't have all that great of a story in and of itself. You can take the sides of either the Resistance or the Ark Security forces, fighting each other for the fate of Ark. Nonetheless, story notwithstanding, the action is fast, gunplay better, and for sure this game is worth a try at least. Overall Score: 9.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 21, 2012
												EDIT:  I'm leaving the full review here, just so you can see, but I have to change to negative.  Brink itself isn't a terrible game (read below if you want to read why I think that), BUT it has no real community to play with and there are newer, better FPS games in all styles.  I suggest checking out Pay Day 2 and Counter Strike: Global Offensive (if you're not a big fan of the standard competeive CS mode, check out Deathmatch and Arms Race, so much fun).Original Review:  A lot has been said about Brink, and a lot of it has been negative.  I must point out that a lot of the bad press the game recieved on launch was due to technical issues on consoles, not on PC.  There were a few minor issues on PC, but all has been fixed with updates to the game.Upon first playing Brink I thought it was brilliant.  The objective system, which gaves you actual goals to accomplish instead of just capturing points, flags, or getting kills, was unique and made the first few hours of gameplay feel new and different, despite otherwise being a standard team-based FPS.  The parkour system is also unique and allows you to traverse levels in interesting ways that other FPS's never will.These combined, plus a neat art aesthetic and customizable characters, made me really enjoy Brink at first.That said, the game didn't really seem to last long for me.  Perhaps it was the fact that the multiplayer is essentially dead (due to the bad rep the game had on release), or maybe the objective system, though unique at first, in practice only seems adds a simple layer on top of "capture this point" mechanics after a couple matches.Maybe the gunplay just doesn't hold up as well to other giants of the FPS genre (specifically Battlefield, as that's what I've had the msot experience with).In short, if you don't mind bot games (or can convince friends to join you), this game is good for perhaps a few hours of FPS fun, but you'll probably get tired of it after 5 or so hours.  I'd say if it's on sale for five bucks, why not give it a shot?  But otherwise, you might as well avoid.Leaving this as a recommendation for the positives, and I would say give it a shot if you can get it cheap and especially if you have friends to play with, so it doesn't exactly deserve a no.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2011
												Don't buy this. Not now, not ever. Even though the main selling point is movement, maps don't reflect that, and you can jump higher in Battlefield Bad Company 2.The weapon balance is pathetic: Heavy weapons are useless, medium weapons are unnecessary and the only light weapon worth a damn is the Bulpdein.The maps are tiny and claustrophobic, even when the game tries to give you a big environment, there's no helping that feeling when you can only ever run along a few corridors in there. Despite the movement system, there's almost no vertical combat, at any given time, the most number of floors you'll see is two, and even then there's virtually no chance that being on either gives you much advantage.The UI looks like it was made by someone who'd only heard of an FPS once. Everything is opposite of where you'd expect and nothing looks explicitly like it should. The radar, in particular needs a border, and more flamboyant blips.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 14, 2011
												Brink is one of the better squad-based FPSs to come out within the last year. The gunplay and character controls feel spot-on, and they're married with an elegant teamplay mechanic and fantastic graphic and audio design. Although the parkour is woefully underused by the players, mastery of this mechanic brings Brink up to one of my favorite shooters of all time. The parkour mechanic, like the Battlefield franchise's Destruction mechanic, will become genre-defining with time. Other shooters now feel incomplete without it.Unfortunately, there are some under-the-hood issues with matchmaking and high-end graphic settings. Brink is also a complete mess on the consoles. Despite these flaws, I still have more fun with Brink than I do with all other shooters save BFBC2.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2011
												Endlich kommt es einmal nicht nur auf die K/D an. In diesem schnellen und Objecitve basierten Mulitplayer-Shooter ist Teamplay das A und O. Selbst der versierteste Schütze kommt nicht weit wenn er sich nicht nach seinen Mitspielern umsieht. Die Karten sind abwechsungsreich und spannend designt. Auch nach vielen Stunden entdeckt man noch neue Wege. Top: Was man offline freischaltet darf man auch online verwenden! Trotzdem kann man keinen Über-Char erstellen. Durch das (großzügige) Levelcap ist man angehalten herauszufinden welche Fähigkeiten zum eigenen Spieltyp passen und diese dan clever auswählen. Gelungen auch die Bots. Sie erfüllen Ziele. Sie verteidigen. Sie flankieren. Sie nehmen Komandoposten. Sie greifen in Wellen an. Sie legen gegen Ende der Partie noch zu. Sie sliden um Dich zu Fall zu bringen... Vor allem aber: Sind sie unterstützen Dich mit "Buffs" und das zum Teil deutlich effektiver als mancher Spawn-Chiller, den ich online im Team hatte :-)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												Underrated game. Reinstalled this at a whim... had forgotten how good it was. Think Team Fortress meets Call of Duty: Modern Warfare. The AI isn't as good as say Counter-Strike: Global Offensive, but they are above average. It has a single player campaign which can be co-op'ed or solo'd. Playing online with hmans is pretty much the game's bread & butter. The game supports LAN and also allows the player to host a dedicated server. Oh, and the graphics still hold up well today; certainly hard to believe it's using the old id Tech4 engine (makes Borderlands 2 and Bioshock: Infinite look dated).Pretty much the quality type stuff you'd expect from Splash Damage. It's just a shame this title did not sell as well as everyone hoped it would. Maybe there's something to be said about console dumb-down...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 20, 2016
												This game was weirdly received so I'll try to provide some clarity. It's a good time if you wanna play a different shooter and mod a character and guns to fit the role you've chosen. The Lamented Features: The "Campaign" is multiplayer missions with bots. Challenges aren't a static difficulty as they will adopt a higher difficulty, causing some to be nigh impossible. Do them first on easy to ensure they're completed.Harder Bots have insane accuracy, requiring around the corner tactics, especially when grouped on an objective. Some objectives require time, and if interupted will be reset. The Sweetness:The Free Running is fun and useful. Character and Weapon Customization is really fun and strategic. I miss it. The Music is great. The Character Art Style is interesting, and well enough received it's in future titles. The Levels are cool looking, ranging from start futurism to busy slums. Fun Mission Types

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 20, 2012
												Brink is an objective based multiplayer shooter that took me some getting used to. Most of my early hours, I was pretty much just killing bad guys while being completely lost on what the objectives were. Now that I have a few more hours under my belt and have gotten used to the gameplay, I must confess it's pretty fun. It's highly action packed, but the objectives are just not obvious to new players.The game puts significant emphasis on customization in both character looks and loadouts--for example being able to select two primary weapons is nice. The graphics are solid, the gameplay is smooth, and the character leveling is implemented well. It also throws in a decent storyline which is uncommon in these type of multiplayer games. But don't buy Brink because of its single player or coop claims. It disappoints unless you consider playing multiplayer with bots fun.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2011
												The game is not♥♥♥♥♥♥ but it is the definition of mediocre. For everything the game does well (parkouring) it loses in its absolutely terrible map design, weapon "upgrade" (read replacement) systems, as well as its mission. Weapons are either ridiculously strong, or so weak as to be puny.The mission objectives system is nicely implemented but does not taking into consideration such things as "that big♥♥♥♥♥♥♥wall in the way". The missions themselves are likewise poorly constructed and suffer far too much from "narrow hallway, open exposed mission area, and enemys spawn on top of your mission objective"It's never clear enough precisely what areas are parkourable and which areas are walls that you just can't touch.To give it, its positives the combat can be engaging at times - the character creator is interesting but as a point of annoyance - you can only create male characters. The entire game world is composed entirely of males.tl;dr - buy something else.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												I like this game. I like the dystopian future theme, the dual campaigns, the rewards system and customisation, the story, the look of the characters, the voices and the movement system. At first it took me a while to get into, but now I am eager for more.Sad truth, however, is there won't be more of Brink. Two customisation DLC's and one set of 4 missions (2 on each campaign), seems to be as good as it's going to get. I haven't played any of the online matches, although according to many reviews, there are rarely any, but that doesn't bother me. I enjoyed the single player mode and I really do wish there were more DLC's and content packages, as this game has wormed its way into my favourites. I enjoyed every single moment of the campaign and would gladly love to see more of it. In a nutshell, a good single player game with an absurd amount of customisation options.

												If you want a game that was super overhyped, was nothing like what was promised, and will make you quit playing within a week of buying it this game is for you. If you like lots of weapons that all feel the same, where it takes just running around spamming a mag at a time to kill people in cqb. Buy this game now. If you like all boxy room maps with no real imagination behind them, then this game was a match made in heaven for you. If all the ads and dev videos being rendered wasn't a hint enough for you that the gameplay wasn't going to be as promised, then check out the number of people playing now. If you want a multi player game that has no people playing it, then this game is perfect. The bots on your team have all suffered from blunt force trauma to the head so they act like a re-tard-ed puppy. I was stupid enough to buy this game full price, why don't you be a jackass and buy it too, so we can all have it uninstalled on steam?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 6, 2011
												Another game I do not regret buying! Brink is sort of like a mixture between Team Fortress and Modern Warfare, with the ability to traverse the battlegrounds using Parkour. The action is fast and furious with an emphasis on completing objectives and assisting team-mates rather than notching up individual kills. You have the option of customizing your characters cosmetically and there is a simple and uncomplicated skill leveling system. There are just a handful of weapon classes so its not a diverse range, but each handles differently. Graphics are great! Maps look excellent and "feel" very natural, soundtrack is bloody excellent and evocative, adds a lot of atmosphere to the game, storyline and themes show a depth rarely explored in games. Voice acting is very good and creates very vivid characters just by that alone. Single player campaign is short, shorter than those of other FPS'es, and mostly for the story. A good team for multiplayer play is recommended.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2011
												How is this♥♥♥♥♥♥still $50. The game tries to be TF2 and failed miserabley. You have to unlock 90% of your class abilites but unlock all guns and gun upgrades by completing some boring challenges that take an hour. Weapons are determined by body type not class, which really makes classes seem irrelevant. The Devs could of made this game way better by having no classes and letting the player chose the abilities they unlock.The graphics seem to imply some sort of cartoon humor but there is none. The amount of character customization is least lacking which is an outrage considering it's the the least game changing and most pointless part of the game. Parkour is pretty useless and irelevant unless you play with the light body type.The "campaign" is just multiplayer with AI. The free DLC simply shows the developers plan on following Call Of Duty's footsteps and selling updates for their game instead of providing them for free. This game is worth about $20

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2012
												Brink is a team-based first-person shooter set in a sci-fi universe. Players choose classes of characters to use in battle in a way very similar to Team Fortress 2, but with the additional player-chosen variable of their body being light, medium, or heavy weight. The campaign is nearly non-existent, with exhbition matches making up its entirety, and the online multiplayer consists of these exhibition matches but with players instead of bots. The maps are clunky and do not direct traffic well, and last time I checked the online community was waning. Overall, it feels unfinished.5.5/10Reasonable Price: $4.99

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 13, 2012
												Don't waste your money, even on sale. All in all you get only about 12 missions, 6 per story line, and only a few hours of real game play. The different classes don't get distinguished enough until you reach some of the very late levels, and you won't play the single player that long. Each mission you have to be the right class for the current objective or you fail as the AI hates to win. It forces wave-spawning, and if you miss the start of a new wave to spawn waiting for a medic, it takes another 20 seconds before you can do anything, and you spawn very far away. You use mainly SMGs, only 4 that are not among about 24 primaries, and side arms are 80% SMGs. Nothing is instantly different between the 2 sides so it's hard to tell what to shoot at unless its got 'enemy' spelled out above it.  The entire story is forced and not engaging. The free movement is fine but needs a different game. Multiplayer is the single player just without bots. This could have been a good game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												Even after 4 years BRINK remains one of the most UNDERRATED games of all time! I reccomend BRINK due to the fact that it's visual style is beautiful! The Ark which is the main setting for the game is full of minty fresh aethetics and designs! The game performs well, movement is parkour based so a lot of running, jump, sliding and wall running. Gun-play is smart, responsive and is rewarding, team play forces you to co-operate with your teammates to complete objectives and progress through the level. Instead of going for a basic team deathmatch or CTF ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, BRINK goes for a more objective based gameplay meaning the objectives are unique and are different for each map and team. The game features some interesting DLC that adds a couple of maps and character customizations and there are a lot of customizations on offer in BRINK!The community is saddly dead which is so unfortunate! Servers are non-existent and I see no-one playing BRINK either! This is a game really to enjoy the visual style and fun gameplay and pretty much nothing else! A huge shame!I still recomend BRINK though due to the amount of fun to be had whilst offline! An exelent game though rushed and killed expectations.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												Where BRINK does some things right, it does many things wrong. When it becomes fun, it has the possibility of becoming equally frustrating. When things start to get exciting, they suddenly become tedious.BRINK had a lot of ambition. A parkour-driven first person shooter with on-the-fly objectives and a campaign that could be played online in both factions at the same time sounded ♥♥♥♥♥♥ic and should have been a recipe for overnight success. Sadly those joyous mechanics were not executed to their fullest potential and the online play was plagued with problems on day one. Now you are lucky to find anyone to play with and playing with the AI can be more frustrating than playing with some hacker ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ online.BRINK is not a bad game, nor is it a good game. It is sadly middle of the road and that hurts. I recommend it only if it is cheap so you can see the makings of what could have been.

Posted: October 3, 2011
												Brink is an immersive first-person shooter that blends single-player, co-op, and multiplayer gameplay into one seamless experience, allowing you to develop your character whether playing alone, with your friends, or against others online. You decide the combat role you want to assume in the world of Brink as you fight to save yourself and mankind’s last refuge. Brink offers a compelling mix of dynamic battlefields, extensive customization options, and an innovative control system that will keep you coming back for more.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 14, 2011
												Brink is one of the better squad-based FPSs to come out within the last year. The gunplay and character controls feel spot-on, and they're married with an elegant teamplay mechanic and fantastic graphic and audio design. Although the parkour is woefully underused by the players, mastery of this mechanic brings Brink up to one of my favorite shooters of all time. The parkour mechanic, like the Battlefield franchise's Destruction mechanic, will become genre-defining with time. Other shooters now feel incomplete without it.Unfortunately, there are some under-the-hood issues with matchmaking and high-end graphic settings. Brink is also a complete mess on the consoles. Despite these flaws, I still have more fun with Brink than I do with all other shooters save BFBC2.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 4, 2011
												This game is not for everyone. Brink is a competitive first-person multiplayer shooter. It is designed to be played online with your friends and not as a singleplayer game, so make no mistake, don't play with bots! However, if you are looking for a multiplayer shooter that does not focus on kills per death ratios or killstreaks, then this game might be for you. Gamers looking for something different and especially fans of the developer's previous game Enemy Territory: Quake Wars will find a game that wants you to play cooperatively with your team in order to defeat the other one. Brink focuses on map-specific objectives that need to be fulfilled to win the map. So if you're looking for a shooter that pushes you so hard to play together, that you will sometimes curse your teammates for not helping you, this is your game. The most issues the game had at its release were fixed up until now, which makes the game highly recommendable to me.

												This game is bad, sadly, like many others I bought into the hype and false advertising that the devs released with their claims of "Redefining FPS". Now-a days I only play it every now and then for a quick round because I lack any other modern FPS to get a quick fix with.The AI is terrible, the campaign is extremely short and poorly structured, the story is barely there and feels like it was tacked onto a series of pre-built objective maps designed solely for multiplayer. The asthetic of the game isn't too bad, some maps look absolutely disgusting and the characters look odd in customization, but when out in the field they seem to look quite a bit better in the proper setting. The character customization, although extremely limited wasn't a bad feature, though the way they abused their limited customization by adding DLC to offer more 'customization' was absolutely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												(mini-review)I had high-hopes for this shooter, by the makers of Enemy Territory: Quake Wars. Instead, what I got was a game that was a complete failure from the get-go. Despite running on the Doom 3 engine (idTech 4), the game was a slow, stuttery, unstable mess. Graphical glitches abounded, with many ATi users reporting scan lines across their screen and sub-par performance to boot(I can attest to these glitches as I experienced both). Rather than fix the problem, Splash Damage tried to bury any evidence of complaints and only responded/fixed the majority of the issues after the potentially fun multiplayer component withered on the vine. The game is fixed now but no one plays it and no one ever will.Splash Damage lost all credibility with me. Developers, when will you learn that responsible ownership for mistakes will always gain you more respect that a brazen money-grab? Good luck making minigames.Avoid this title.4/10.
